It depends on the terminology. Photons indeed have no rest mass, but do have an effective mass. (Just like when you accelerate a massive particle, its rest mass remains the same, but its effective - relativistic - mass increases in proportion to its kinetic energy, as described by Einstein's energy-mass equivalence formula E=m*c^2. This also allows us to measure the mass of particles in electron-volts; e.g. when an electron and a positron at low speed annihilate into photons, their energy will be equivalent to to the particles' mass.)

Finally: E/c = momentum.     The reason why the Change in momentum with light sails is so little is because the denominator is the constant, approx 299,000,000m/s. The larger the denominator, the smaller the Change in momentum.

The mechanism by which photons transmit momentum is also very interesting and should be mentioned. The photon can be thought of as changing electric and magnetic fields oscillating at 90 degrees to each other perpendicular to the direction of the photon. Each changing field induces the other as described by the Faraday and Ampere-Maxwell laws. Charged particles in the sail will move in the electric field. But this means they are moving perpendicularly to the magnetic field, so by the Lorentz force law they feel a force in the forward direction.  Using the right hand rule for the fields inducing each other and for the directions of the charged particles in the magnetic field makes this clear.
